[30;1m164 | [0m[35mThese functions can roughly be described as duplicating the "authentication" functionality of `iinit[0m
[30;1m165 | [0m[35mprovided that a valid `irods_environment.json` has already been created.[0m
[30;1m166 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m167 | [0m[35mEach of the above functions can take a cleartext password and write an appropriately encoded[0m
[30;1m168 | [0m[35mversion of it into an authentication file in the appropriate location.  That location is[0m
[30;1m169 | [0m[35m`~/.irods/.irodsA` unless the environment variable IRODS_AUTHENTICATION_FILE has been set[0m
[30;1m170 | [0m[35min the command shell to dictate an alternative file path.[0m

[30;1m216 | [0m[35m```[0m

[30;1m219 | [0m[35m**Warning:** Disabling the SSL requirement may cause user passwords to be sent over the network[0m
[30;1m220 | [0m[35min the clear. This should only be done for purposes of testing. Here's how to do it:[0m
[30;1m221 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m198 | [0m[35mFor the `pam_password` scheme, typically SSL/TLS must first be enabled to avoid sending data related[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m128[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000701[0m

[30;1m164 | [0m[35mThese functions can roughly be described as duplicating the "authentication" functionality of `iinit[0m
[30;1m165 | [0m[35mprovided that a valid `irods_environment.json` has already been created.[0m
[30;1m166 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m167 | [0m[35mEach of the above functions can take a cleartext password and write an appropriately encoded[0m
[30;1m168 | [0m[35mversion of it into an authentication file in the appropriate location.  That location is[0m
[30;1m169 | [0m[35m`~/.irods/.irodsA` unless the environment variable IRODS_AUTHENTICATION_FILE has been set[0m
[30;1m170 | [0m[35min the command shell to dictate an alternative file path.[0m

[30;1m144 | [0m[35mAt this point, we are ready to instantiate and use the session:[0m
[30;1m145 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m201 | [0m[35mThus, for `pam_password` authentication to work well, we should first ensure, when setting up the[0m
[30;1m202 | [0m[35mclient environment, to include within `irods_environment.json` the appropriate SSL/TLS connection[0m
[30;1m203 | [0m[35mparameters.  In a pinch, `iinit` can be used to verify this prerequisite is fulfilled,[0m
[30;1m204 | [0m[35mas its invocation would then create a valid `.irodsA` from merely prompting the user for their PAM p[0m
[30;1m205 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m134[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m90 | [0m[35mIf no `client_zone` is provided, the `zone` parameter is used in its place.[0m

[30;1m228 | [0m[35m```[0m

[30;1m174 | [0m[35mFor the `pam_password` scheme, typically SSL/TLS must first be enabled to avoid sending data related[0m
[30;1m175 | [0m[35mto the password - or even sending the raw password itself - over a network connection in the clear.[0m

[30;1m170 | [0m[35mThe redirect may of course be left off, in which case the user is prompted for the iRODS password[0m
[30;1m171 | [0m[35mand echo of the keyboard input will be suppressed, in the style of `iinit`.  Regardless of[0m
[30;1m172 | [0m[35mwhich technique is used, no password will be visible on the terminal during or after input.[0m
[30;1m173 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m171[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m164 | [0m[35mEquivalently to the above, we can issue the following command.[0m
[30;1m165 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m154 | [0m[35m          ... # other parameters as needed[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m173[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m146 | [0m[35min the command shell to dictate an alternative file path.[0m
[30;1m147 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m148 | [0m[35mAs an example, here we write a native `.irodsA` file using the first of the two functions.  We[0m
[30;1m149 | [0m[35mprovide the one required argument, a password string which is entered interactively at the[0m
[30;1m150 | [0m[35mterminal.[0m
[30;1m151 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m152 | [0m[35m```bash[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m174[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m
   Rule Id: [34mBD000701[0m
       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.DataExfiltration.Token[0m
  Severity: [36mImportant[0m, Confidence: [36mHigh[0m
  Filename: [33m/python_irodsclient-3.1.0/README.md[0m
   Pattern: [32m(npm owner|password|htpasswd|auth_?token|secret_?key|private_?key|authorized_keys?|npmrc|\.ssh|usersecrets?|api_?keys|nuget\.config|\.identityservice)[0m
[30;1m140 | [0m[35mThese functions can roughly be described as duplicating the "authentication" functionality of `iinit[0m
[30;1m141 | [0m[35mprovided that a valid `irods_environment.json` has already been created.[0m
[30;1m142 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m143 | [0m[35mEach of the above functions can take a cleartext password and write an appropriately encoded[0m
[30;1m144 | [0m[35mversion of it into an authentication file in the appropriate location.  That location is[0m
[30;1m145 | [0m[35m`~/.irods/.irodsA` unless the environment variable IRODS_AUTHENTICATION_FILE has been set[0m
[30;1m146 | [0m[35min the command shell to dictate an alternative file path.[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m175[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m120 | [0m[35mAt this point, we are ready to instantiate and use the session:[0m
[30;1m121 | [0m[35m[0m

[30;1m95 | [0m[35m    """Write the credentials to an .irodsA file that will enable logging in with PAM authentication[0m

[30;1m961 | [0m[35mApplication Cleanup[0m
[30;1m962 | [0m[35m-------------------[0m
[30;1m963 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m964 | [0m[35mUsing the `irods.at_client_exit` module, we may register user-defined functions to be executed at or[0m
[30;1m965 | [0m[35mtime when the Python iRODS Client is engaged in object teardown (also called "cleanup") operations.[0m
[30;1m966 | [0m[35mThis is analogous to Python's [atexit module](https://docs.python.org/3/library/atexit.html#module-a[0m
[30;1m967 | [0m[35mexcept that here we have the extra resolution to specify that a function or callable object be expre[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m686[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m826 | [0m[35mThe list of operations are applied in the order given, so that a[0m
[30;1m827 | [0m[35m"remove" followed by an "add" of the same AVU is, in effect, a[0m
[30;1m828 | [0m[35mmetadata "set" operation. Also note that a "remove" operation will[0m
[30;1m829 | [0m[35mbe ignored if the AVU value given does not exist on the target object at[0m
[30;1m830 | [0m[35mthat point in the sequence of operations.[0m
[30;1m831 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m832 | [0m[35mWe can also source from a pre-built list of AVUOperations using[0m
[30;1m833 | [0m[35mPython's `f(*args_list)` syntax. For example, this[0m

[30;1m1783 | [0m[35mto `<session>.permissions`, except that the[0m

[30;1m1434 | [0m[35mIn the above loop we have used a helper function, *get_collection*, to[0m

[30;1m1437 | [0m[35mqueried at a high rate of redundancy. *get_collection* can be[0m

[30;1m325 | [0m[35mOther progress bars may be included in an updatables parameter, but may require more extensive adapt[0m
[30;1m326 | [0m[35mFor example, the ProgressBar object (from the progressbar module) also has an update method, but it[0m
[30;1m327 | [0m[35mtakes an up-to-date cumulative byte-count, instead of the size of an individual transfer in bytes,[0m
[30;1m328 | [0m[35mas its sole parameter.  There can be other complications:  e.g. a ProgressBar instance does not allo[0m

[30;1m1742 | [0m[35mGetting and setting permissions[0m
[30;1m1743 | [0m[35m-------------------------------[0m
[30;1m1744 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m1745 | [0m[35mWe can find the ID's of all the collections writable (i.e. having[0m

[30;1m1747 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m1748 | [0m[35m```python[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m1039[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

[30;1m1612 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m1613 | [0m[35m  data.replicate(**{kw.DEST_RESC_NAME_KW: 'dest'})[0m
[30;1m1614 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m1615 | [0m[35m  # Find and trim replicas on the source resource hierarchy.[0m

[30;1m1600 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m1601 | [0m[35mWe'll assume, for our current purposes, that all pre-existing replicas are good (ie. they have a[0m
[30;1m1602 | [0m[35m`status` attribute of `'1'`); and that the nodes in question are named `src` and `dest`,[0m
[30;1m1603 | [0m[35mwith `src` being the root node of a resource hierarchy and `dest` just a simple storage node.[0m
[30;1m1604 | [0m[35m[0m
[30;1m1605 | [0m[35mThen we can accomplish the replica "move" thus:[0m
[30;1m1606 | [0m[35m[0m

[31m--[ [0m[34mMatch #[0m[33m1041[0m[34m of [0m[33m1420[0m[31m ]--[0m

       Tag: [34mSecurity.Backdoor.LOLBAS.Linux[0m
